## {#alge-rules data-menu-title="Rules of Algebra"}

[Rules of Algebra]{.slide-title}

<hr>

1.  Never change an equation. Instead, we rewrite them into more useful forms

2.  Manipulate BOTH sides of an equation with the SAME PROCEDURE.

<span style="color: red;">
Always add/substract/multiply/divide by the same number on both sides. More generally, always apply the same function to both sides of the equation. 
</span>

3.  Order of Operations, a.k.a. PEDMAS: (P)aranthesis (E)xponents (D)ivide (M)ultiply (A)dd (S)ubtract

## {#pedmas-use-2 data-menu-title="PEDMAS important for what order to manipulate equations"}

[PEDMAS important for what order to manipulate equations]{.slide-title}

<hr>

If we are given the values of $x=-3$ and $y=2$, what would be the value of $z$?

üí° [Let's see a solution!]{style="color:green;"}

$$
\begin{align}
z &= 4*(y-4)+(x+1)^2 \\
  &= 4*(2-4)+(-3+1)^2 \\
  &= 4*(-2)+(-2)^2 \\
  &= -8 + 4 \\
  &= -4.
\end{align}
$$

## {#flex-eq-3 data-menu-title="Often times we want flexible equations"}

[Often times we want flexible equations]{.slide-title}

<hr>

üí° [Let's see a solution!]{style="color:green;"}

Prices are important in economics, but not always available for environmental goods. 

<br>

:::{.center-text}
**How do we get prices if we know quantity?**
:::

$$
\require{cancel}
\begin{aligned}
Q&=\frac{(400-P)}{80} &\text{Isolate P in terms of Q} \\
80Q&=\frac{(400-P)\cancel{80}}{\cancel{80}}  &\text{ Multiply both sides by 80} \\
80Q-400&=\cancel{400}-\cancel{400} -P &\text{ Subtract both sides by 400} \\
-1(80Q-400)&=-P(-1) &\text{Multiply both sides by -1} \\
400-80Q&=P  &\text{Flip terms for simplicity}
\end{aligned}
$$

## {#practice-alge-4 data-menu-title="Solutions"}

[Practice Solutions]{.slide-title}

<hr>

:::columns

:::{.column width=50%}
$$
\small
\begin{aligned}
3x+2&=10x-12 \\
3x+2+12&=10x-12(+12) \\
3x-3x+14&=10x-3x \\
14&=7x \\
x&=2
\end{aligned}
$$
<br>

$$
\small
\begin{aligned}
4-3(2x+1)&=8-\frac{3x}{2}\\
4-3-6x&=8-\frac{3x}{2} \\
1-6x&=8-\frac{3x}{2} \\
2-12x&=16-3x \\
-9x&=14 \\
x&=\frac{-14}{9}\\
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

:::{.column width=50%}
$$
\small
\begin{aligned}
3(x+7a)-5&=b+2(c-4x)\\
3x+21a-5&=b+2c-8x \\
11x+21a-5&=b+2c \\
11x&=5+b+2c-21a\\
x&=\frac{5+b+2c-21a}{11}
\end{aligned}
$$
:::

## {#exponents data-menu-title="Exponents"}

[Exponents make algebra more interesting!]{.slide-title}

<hr>

**Example**

The expression $x^3$ means $x$ multiplied by itself 3 times:
$$x^3=x * x * x$$

. . .

More generally, 
$$x^n = x \text{ to the power of } n.$$

. . .

Intuitively, the **exponent** $n$ tells us how many times to multiply the **basis** $x$ by itself:

$$x^n = \underbrace{x * x * ... * x}_{n \text{ times}}$$

But the exponent can be any (real) number, not only integers!
<!--------------------------------------------------------------------------->

## {#exponents-rules-1 data-menu-title="Exponents Rules (1)"}
[Rules and properties of exponents (1)]{.slide-title}

<hr>
(1) Product rule: $x^a * x^b = x^{a+b}$

<br>

(2) Quotient rule: $\frac{x^a}{x^b} = x^{a-b}, \ \ \text{for } x \neq 0$

<br>

(3) Any non-negative $x$ to the power of 0 equals 1: $x^0 = 1, \ \ \text{for } x \neq 0$

<br>

(4) Negative exponent means divide: $x^{-a} = \frac{1}{x^a}, \ \ \text{for } x \neq 0$

<br>

(5) Fractional exponent means take the $n$-th root: $x^{\frac{1}{n}} = \sqrt[n]{x}$

<!--------------------------------------------------------------------------->
## {#exponents-rules-2 data-menu-title="Exponents Rules (2)"}
[Rules and properties of exponents (2)]{.slide-title}

<hr>

(6) Power of a power means multiply the exponents: $(x^a)^b = x^{ab}$

<br>

(7) Exponents get distributed over products: $(xy)^a = x^a y^a$

<br>

(8) And exponents get distributed over divisions: $\left( \frac{x}{y} \right)^a = \frac{x^a}{y^a}$

<br>

(9) If $a$ is the $n$-th root of $x$, then $a$ to the $n$ equals $x$:

$$
a = \sqrt[n]{x} \Rightarrow a^n = x
$$

## {#exponents-table data-menu-title="Rules of exponents"}

[Rules and properties of exponents]{.slide-title}
<hr>

$$
\begin{array}{|l|l|}
\hline
\textbf{Rule} & \textbf{Expression} \\
\hline
\text{Product Rule} & x^{a} \cdot x^{b} = x^{a+b} \\
\hline
\text{Quotient Rule} & \frac{x^{a}}{x^{b}} = x^{a-b}, \quad x \neq 0 \\
\hline
\text{Zero Exponent} & x^{0} = 1, \quad x \neq 0 \\
\hline
\text{Negative Exponent} & x^{-a} = \frac{1}{x^{a}}, \quad x \neq 0 \\
\hline
\text{Fractional Exponent} & x^{\frac{1}{n}} = \sqrt[n]{x} \\
\hline
\text{Power of a Power} & (x^{a})^{b} = x^{ab} \\
\hline
\text{Power of a Product} & (xy)^{a} = x^{a}y^{a} \\
\hline
\text{Power of a Quotient} & \left(\frac{x}{y}\right)^{a} = \frac{x^{a}}{y^{a}} \\
\hline
\text{$n$-th Root Definition} & a = \sqrt[n]{x} \quad \Rightarrow \quad a^{n} = x \\
\hline
\end{array}
$$

## {#polynomials data-menu-title="Polynomials"}

[Polynomials describe more complex relationships through exponents]{.slide-title}

<hr>

A polynomial is a function of the form:
$$
\large
\begin{align}
a_nx^n+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+...+a_1x+a_0
\end{align}
$$

- $x$ is the **variable** 
- $a_i$ are **constants** (fixed numbers) that are called the **coefficients** of the polynomial
- each $a_ix^i$ is called a **term** of the polynomial,
- $n$ is called the **degree** of the polynomial, this is the largest exponent in the polynomial.

. . . 

*Example:*

- $x^5 + x^2 - 1$ is a polynomial of degree five with three terms.

- Linear functions like $mx + c$ where $m$ and $c$ are constants are polynomials of degree 1!

Polynomials often represent real world data better than a linear function.


<!--------------------------------------------------------------------------->
## {#fundamental data-menu-title="Fundamental Theorem of Algebra"}

[Fundamental Theorem of Algebra]{.slide-title}

<hr>

<br>

A **zero**, **root**, or **solution** for a polynomial is a value of $x$ that makes the polynomial equal to zero.

<!--
<img src="images/polynomial_zeros.png" width="250"/>

![](images/polynomial_zeros.png)
-->

<br>

. . .

:::{.center-text .body-text-m}
*Fundamental Theorem of Algebra*
:::
A polynomial
$$
a_nx^n+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+...+a_1x+a_0
$$

of degree $n$ has exactly $n$ roots $r_1, \ldots, r_n$ and it can be refactored as

$$
c(x-r_1) ... (x-r_n)
$$

The numbers $c$ and $r_1, \ldots, r_n$ may be complex!

<!--------------------------------------------------------------------------->
## {#example-linear data-menu-title="Example: linear equation"}

[Example: linear equation]{.slide-title}

<hr>

- A linear equation is just a 1st degree polynomial. How many solutions does it have?

$$
3x+2=10x-12
$$

This can be rewritten as:

$$
x - 2 = 0.
$$

So $r_1 = 2$ is the root. There is a single root because the degree is 1.

. . . 

<br>

Finding the roots of $n$-th degree polynomials is much harder - we will let computers do it for us.

- Let's zoom in on 2nd degree polynomials

## {#example-second-degree data-menu-title="Example: second degree"}

[Example: second degree polynomial]{.slide-title}

<hr>
What happens if $x=4$ or $x=-3$ in  $x^2-x-12$?

<br>

:::{.incremental}

- This means 4 and 3 are roots of the polynomial $x^2-x-12$. 

<br>

- The only way to get $x^2-x-12=0$ is for $x$ to either be 4 or -3.

<br>

- We can rewrite 
$$x^2-x-12 = (x-4)(x+3).$$

<br>

- Verify the factorization on the right. 
:::

## {#quad data-menu-title="Quadratic Formula"}

[Quadratic Formula solves 2nd degree polynomials]{.slide-title}

<hr>

**For any second degree polynomial**

$$
ax^2+bx+c=0
$$

**The roots to can be found using the quadratic formula:**

$$
x=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}
$$

. . .

*Example:*

 Let's use the quadratic formula to find the solutions to $x^2-x-12=0$.

## {#xy-coordinates data-menu-title="xy coordinates"}

[The $xy$ coordinate system]{.slide-title}

<hr>

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}

Graphs move in a 2-dimensional plane with a coordinate system using two axes:

- $x$-axis (horizontal axis)

- $y$-axis (vertical axis)


<br>

Axes units must be defined depending on the application.

:::{.incremental}

We use pairs of numbers to place data:

- A point on the $xy$ plane with **coordinates** $(a,b)$ means the point is located at $a$ on the $x$-axis and at $b$ on the $y$-axis.

- Where would (2,-1) go on the graph?

```{r echo=FALSE}
x=seq(0,10,by=0.01)
```

## {#slope-int data-menu-title="Slope-Intercept Form"}

[Linear functions: slope-intercept form]{.slide-title}

<hr>

Easiest model to describe linear relationship between two variables!

$$
\huge
\begin{align}
\underbrace{y}_{\text{output}}=\overbrace{m}^{\text{Slope}}\underbrace{x}_{\text{input}}+\overbrace{b}^{\text{$y$ intercept}}
\end{align}
$$

<br>

- The **slope** tells us how quickly is the line changing. 


## {#slope-def data-menu-title="Definition of Slope"}

[How to calculate the slope?]{.slide-title}

<hr>

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}


Slope = 

vertical change per unit of horizontal change.

$$
m=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}
$$

Horizontal Slope: $m=0$

Vertical Slope: $m$ is undefined

:::

:::{.column width="50%"}

:::{.center-text}
**Rise over Run**
:::

```{r echo=FALSE,fig.align='center',out.width="80%"}
knitr::include_graphics("images/slope.PNG")
```

:::

## {#ta-q2 data-menu-title="Team Assesment 2"}

<!--TODO: we need some equitable way of having them interact with each other.-->

Your team measured the concentrations of pesticides in a lake exposed to agricultural runoff. You have the following equation describing the total amount of pesticides in the lake if runoff is stopped from the farm by a new policy incentive reducing pesticides use:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&y=(8-2t)(t+2) \\
&\text{Where } y \text{ is pesticde concentration in ppb} \\
&\text{and } t \text{ is time in years}.
\end{aligned}
$$

Work with your team to 

- **first** discuss conceptually how you would solve *all* the following tasks, do not write anything!

- **second** work out with pen and paper the solutions to verify the ideas you discussed.

1) What kind of equation is this? Would it be useful to write it in another form?

2) How long will it take for the pesticide concentration in the lake to reach zero? Since the equation is a polynomial describe why one solution is more applicable than the other.

3) Present your findings (choose between a graph or table).

4) What is the average change in concentration from year 0 to year 4?

5) Explain to your client why concentrations might behave the way they were modeled.

## {#ta-sol21 data-menu-title="Team Assesment 2 Solutions"}

[Solution 1]{.slide-title}
<hr>

Let's expand out the equation so it becomes easier to graph.

$$
\begin{aligned}
y&=(-2t+8)(t+2) \\
y&=\overbrace{-2t^2}^{\text{First}}-\overbrace{4t}^{\text{Outside}}+\overbrace{8t}^{\text{Inside}}+\overbrace{16}^{\text{Last}}\\
y&=-2t^2+4t+16
\end{aligned}
$$

## {#ta-q2-sol2 data-menu-title="Team Assesment 2 Solutions"}

[Solution 2]{.slide-title}
<hr>

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}

:::{.center-text}
Use the Quadratic Formula
:::

$$
\begin{aligned}
0&=-2t^2+4t+16 \\
0&=\frac{-4\pm\sqrt{4^2-4(-2)(16)}}{2(-2)}\\
0&=\frac{-4\pm\sqrt{16+128}}{-4} \\
&t=4\text{, } t=-2
\end{aligned}
$$
:::
:::{.column width="50%"}
:::{.center-text}
Use the factors
:::

$$
\begin{aligned}
2t-8=0 \\
t=\frac{8}{2}\\
t=4
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

::::

<hr>

::::{.columns}
:::{.column width="50%"}

```{r, echo=FALSE,out.width="90%",fig.dim=c(5,5.5)}

  filter(t>=0) %>%
```

:::{.column width="50%"}
```{r eval=FALSE,echo=TRUE}

  filter(t>=0) %>%

  labs(x="Years",y="Pesticide Concentration")+
```

Use rise over run:

$$
\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=\frac{0-16}{4-0}=-4
$$

Pesticides are removed from the lake at an average rate of 4 ppb per year.
